results.title: Pour la Peau D'un Flic = for a Cop's Hide
results.brief_description:
Choucas, a former cop turned private investigator, is asked by an old lady to investigate the disappearance of a young blind girl. It all seem a very mundane case. But shortly after starting the investigation, Choucas receives the visit of a very strange and nosy person. Then, later on, the old lady is murdered on her way to a meeting with Choucas.

Credits: Producer, director, Alain Delon ; writers, Alain Delon, Christopher Frank ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Oscar Benton ; art direction, Theo Meurisse.
Cast: Alain Delon, Anne Parillaud, Daniel Ceccaldi, Michel Auclair.

results.title: Heart of the matter
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard and Artransa Park Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Live”.
Part of an instructional film series from 1969-70 about the training of Australia’s youth. Thirteen colour films of ten minutes duration were made under the auspices of the Cultural Council for National Fitness. The films focus on National Fitness Camps, sports, family recreation and exercises for people of all ages. Sponsored by the Shell Company, the films were made to emphasis the need for physical fitness amongst all age groups. This film deals with the prevention and rehabilitation of heart disease through exercise.

results.title: Family recreation
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Shell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Live”.
Australians in most walks of life now have more leisure time at their disposal. There are many enjoyable, interesting and healthy ways of utilising this leisure time, and this film gives many suggestions - and much food for thought.

results.title: Pouches rule OK!
results.creator_credit: Richard Corfield and ABC-TV (Australia). Science Unit
results.brief_description: Reporter Geoffrey Burchfield describes an exciting new fossil discovery in central Queensland raises interesting questions about the status on Australia in the evolution of life on earth.

results.title: Fat pizza
results.creator_credit: Paul Fenech, Tanith Carroll, Village Roadshow Pictures and Fat Pizza
results.brief_description: This Australian comedy, based on the SBS television show “Pizza”, has an irreverent anarchic flavour that is certain to (intentionally) offend. Pauly (Paul Fenech) is a pizza delivery boy who works for the explosively bad-tempered Bobo (Johnny Boxer); Pauly’s other main occupation is to drive about in his souped-up car, with its blaring sub-woofer stereo; meanwhile his friends Sleek (Paul Nakad), and Davo (Jabba) similarly cruise around in their own customised vehicle, encountering violent cops and sexually eager women. Fans of the series will recognise the vigour with which writer Fenech attacks sacred cows of Australian culture - principally, but not exclusively, the young male Lebanese/Australian racial stereotype - whilst applying a thick layer of infantile machismo and t&a humour. Certainly not to the taste of all, but quite original and daring in both concept and execution. Cast also incudes Annalise Braakensiek with cameos by Merv Hughes, Tim Ferguson, Jeff Fenech, Shane Porteous, Red Symons, Bernard King and Kamahl.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Fenech, Tanith Carroll, Village Roadshow Pictures and Fat Pizza

results.title: Fat of the land
results.creator_credit: Baptist Pork Production in association with Civilian Tragedy
results.brief_description: A compilation of short British ‘art-house’ films 1984-1987 as follows: “Procar” (dirs. Richard Heslop, Daniel Landin), A Nosegay” (dir. Maggie Jailler), “Thou pluckest me out screaming (dir. Daniel Landin), “Epiphany (excerpt)” (dir. Certh Wyn Evens), “The Sluggard” (dir. Joy Perino), “Language” (dir. Richard Heslop), “Less then useless” (dirs. Richard Heslop, Carrie Kirkpatrick) and “The Conversation” (dirs. Timothy Burke, Richard Heslop)

results.title: Fat girl = For my sister = A ma soeur! [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Breillat, Jean-Francois Lepetit, Urania Pictures, Immagine e Cinema (IT), Flach Film, CB Films (France) and Arte France
results.brief_description: Catherine Breillat (Romance, 36 fillette) courts controversy with this starkly compelling coming of age film. Anais (Anais Reboux) is a depressed and overweight thirteen-year-old girl who lives in the shadow of her beautiful and sexually alluring fifteen-year-old sister, Elena. On holiday with their aloof mother and apathetic father, the sisters meet Fernando, a handsome Italian law student who forms an instantaneous attraction to Elena. Elena is aware of her appeal, although naive about the manipulations of men, and yearns to lose her virginity with someone she loves. Fernando, an experienced sexual predator, sets about conquering Elena through coercion, flattery, guilt inducing overtures and the weight of his experience. Whilst Elena vacillates between acquiescence and resistance, Anais is a mute and unwilling witness. As well as displaying in a confronting manner the deflowering of Elena, Breillat also explores the complex relationship between the sisters that oscillates between abuse and affection, displaying several scenes in which they compare their morality and opposing perspectives about love and sex. Breillat successfully interrogates her subject matter of the abject adolescent condition in a powerful manner allowing much room for viewer contemplation. But a shock ending that taps into Anais’ wish-fulfilment in a most brutal fashion, divided audience and critical reaction. In French with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: Fat girl = For my sister = A ma soeur! [DVD] (E)

results.title: Fat freedom
results.creator_credit: Richard Capaner, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Using soft washes of colour, this animated film portrays a man’s desire to escape his heavy human body, changing it into forms that let him fly, dance and rejoice and allow him to express his inner needs and fantasies. Music by Ben Low.

results.title: Family reactions
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit
results.brief_description: Designed to provide the intellectual disability residential care worker with an insight into what it means to be part of a family that includes a child with developmental disabilities, an understanding of the grieving process and how families cope, an appreciation of the needs of different families, to learn ways of interacting positively with parents, to examine methods of developing effective partnerships with parents and most importantly develop an appreciation of the uniqueness of families and their reactions. Accompanied by 44p. in-service training manual.
